title: 112_hr2867
content:
The Act titled "United States Commission on International Religious Freedom Reform and Reauthorization Act of 2011" establishes terms for Commission members, limiting them to 2 terms of 2 years each. Members cannot serve beyond their term expiration. The Act limits Commission members to two terms of two years each, with a member's term expiring 90 days after the end date. Members attending less than 75% of meetings during a term are ineligible for reappointment. Additionally, no member can serve as Chair for a second consecutive term, and members are subject to federal travel regulations. Members of the Commission are subject to federal travel regulations and antidiscrimination laws for employment rights and protections. The Act of 1998 is amended to include antidiscrimination laws for various employment rights and protections for all employees of the Commission, treating them as employees of the Senate or House of Representatives. Pending claims can still be maintained. The Act of 1998 is amended to include antidiscrimination laws for employment rights and protections for Commission employees, treating them as Senate or House employees. Pending claims can still be maintained. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 2012 through 2014 is approved. Standards of conduct and disclosure are updated, and termination date is extended. SEC. 6. TERMINATION.
    Section 209 of the International Religious Freedom Act of 1998 (22 U.S.C. 6436) is amended by changing the termination date from "September 30, 2011" to "September 30, 2014".
SEC. 7. REPORT ON EFFECTIVENESS OF PROGRAMS TO PROMOTE RELIGIOUS FREEDOM.
    The Comptroller General of the United States is required to submit a report to congressional committees within a year of this Act's enactment, evaluating the implementation and impact of programs promoting international religious freedom. The report will review the effectiveness of US Government programs promoting international religious freedom, assess the roles of the Office on International Religious Freedom and the Ambassador at Large, and evaluate the goals of the US Commission on International Religious Freedom. The curr_chunk discusses the International Religious Freedom Act of 1998, the structure of the United States Commission on International Religious Freedom, and the relationship between the Ambassador at Large for International Religious Freedom and the Commission. It also defines the term "appropriate congressional committees." The curr_chunk discusses the roles of the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the Vice President of the United States as President of the Senate.
